author: Katharine Murphy
title: Australia Post's chief executive Ahmed Fahour expected to quit after pay row | Business | The Guardian
text:
Australia Post's chief executive Ahmed Fahour expected to quit after pay row 
Fahour expected to resign after being told to take a cut to his $5.6m remuneration package The prime minister, Malcolm Turnbull, had told the Australia Post chief that he did not approve of his $5.6m pay package. Photograph: Lukas Coch/AAP View more sharing options Thursday 23 February 2017 01.43 GMT Last modified on Thursday 23 February 2017 01.46 GMT 
Australia Post chief executive Ahmed Fahour is expected to quit as the head of Australia Post on Thursday after a dispute with the Turnbull government about his $5.6m remuneration package. 
Sources have told Guardian Australia that Fahour was told by the government this week he could remain in his job if he agreed to cut his package from the current level of $5.6m – or if he refused, action would be taken against the Post board. 
Fahour’s remuneration has become a matter of significant political controversy in recent weeks, with the prime minister, Malcolm Turnbull, making it clear he had spoken to the chairman of the board to register the government’s disapproval. 
More to come
